intro: Vaccinium decamerocarpon, commonly known as the ten-berried blueberry, is a shrub native to the northern regions of North America. It belongs to the Ericaceae family and is characterized by its small, deciduous leaves and clusters of flowers. The plant produces small, blue-black berries that are edible and often used in culinary applications. It thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is typically found in boreal and temperate forest ecosystems. Vaccinium decamerocarpon plays an important role in supporting local wildlife and maintaining ecological balance in its native habitats.
